results.title: String instruments
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Children’s Concert”
At one of his concerts for Ottawa children, conductor Eugene Kash illustrates points on musical form and introduces the string instruments. When the violin, viola and cello have been presented separately, they join in a fugue, and later Mr. Kash plays a gavotte on his violin. Closing scenes are of a dance by a group of little girls, set to music composed by some of the children themselves.

results.title: String choir
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Portrays the wide variety of musical moods and effects conveyed by stringed instruments and thus demonstrates the reason for their bearing the brunt of orchestral interpretations. Also shows the various techniques of performance.

results.title: Striker
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Israel Hicks, Bernard Devlin and Robert Nichol
results.brief_description: This fictional film tells the tale of Striker Bucknell who throws a party which, if it succeeds, will be his passport to “hell.” The unexpected arrival of Abel and Garth, of the Children of Heaven religious group, disrupts his well-laid plans to win membership in the motorcycle gang, the Sons of Satan.

results.title: Strike your heart (A)
results.creator_credit: Nicki Lukacs, Wayne Barker and Strike Your Heart Productions
results.brief_description: Strike Your Heart is a gentle portrait of change; its happiness and heartbreak for a boy, a family and a culture. It is 1967 and Australian Aborigines have won the battle for their citizenship rights. New attitudes are being embraced by all and for a ten-year-old boy (Rami Rahman) living in the quiet coastal town of Broome, North-Western Australia, there are personal challenges that have to be faced - falling in love, his first kiss, heartbreak and departure from his close-knit Aboriginal family. Filmed on location in Broome, Western Australia - Wayne Barker’s homelands, with an indigenous cast from the region, “Strike Your Heart” is the first indigenous drama made in Western Australia. Cast includes Jimmy Edgar, Petris Torres, Attika Edgar, Alison Torres, Sylvia Clarke, Stephen ‘Baamba’Albert, Emmanuelle Torres, Brian T. Eastwell.

results.title: Strike in town
results.creator_credit: Nicholas Balla, ONF | NFB and Leslie McFarlane
results.brief_description:
The threat of a strike nobody wants, but which everyone seems powerless to avert, lends suspense to this story of events leading to a deadlock in negotiations between the management and employees of a furniture factory. Staged against the background of a small one-industry town, this dramatisation shows the normal processes of collective bargaining common to Canadian industry today and how they affect a union, a company and a community.
(Award: Chicago.)

results.title: Strike
results.brief_description: At the time of “Strike”, his first film, Eisenstein was a director of the Proletkult Theatre, an organisation with a boldly original technique of acting which led him logically to the medium of the cinema. The film has little formal plot in the conventional sense; a characteristic brilliance of wit and image association here achieves an almost surrealistic intensity. The photography often achieves effects reminiscent of the ‘metaphysical objects’ school of painting.

results.title: Stride to glory: a history of African Americans in the Olympic Games
results.brief_description: For as long as there has been the Olympic Games there has been the participation of African Americans and the sporting arena has provided them with an important avenue for expression. This program traces some of the key achievements and milestones of athletes at the Olympics (both Winter and Summer Games): the first male and female medal recipients; first individual gold; first team event, as well as placing the success of groups and individuals into the wider context of their success in sport in general, especially in relation to boxing and basketball. Involvement throughout each game is mentioned, with emphasis placed on some of the names synonymous with African American athletes: George Pogue; Jim Thorpe; Alice Coachman; Mae Fagg; Arthur Ashe; Rafer Johnson; Anite De Frantz and Wilma Randolph to name a few.
